title: Projects
text:
For this project, I used ArcGIS Pro to analyze and visualize cyanobacterial blooms in Pyramid Lake, NV. NDVI was calculated from Landsat 8-9 imagery for four bloom events, and a threshold of 0.25 was applied to identify areas of potential cyanobacterial activity. The slider app above displays a vectorized representation of NDVI for blooms that occurred on 10/29/2017, 9/22/2021, 10/6/2023 and 10/8/2024.
View the StoryMap here: Pyramid Lake Cyanobacterial Blooms

title: Hydrology
text:
Trout Creek was historically one of the most productive fisheries in the Tahoe Basin. In 1859, logging began in the Trout Creek Area. During the logging period, 13 miles of railroad, 16 miles of wagon haul roads, 2 miles of “V” flume and 28 logging camps were constructed in the Trout Creek watershed, causing erosion along Trout Creek and Saxton Creek (TRCD, 2013). Post-logging, the Trout Creek watershed was used to graze cattle and sheep. During this time, a ditch system and a series of small dams were developed along the tributaries of Trout Creek and Cold Creek (TRCD, 2013). Excessive grazing degraded watershed conditions. In 1996, the dams were removed from Cold Creek (California Tahoe Conservancy, 2022). Since 1996, projects within the Trout Creek watershed were conducted to restore the watershed to its historic condition. In 2021, the Caldor Fire burned areas within the Trout Creek Watershed, affecting the watershed’s streams (California Tahoe Conservancy, 2022). Moving forward, plans are being developed for restoration projects in several sections of Trout Creek and Cold Creek.  
This analysis compares flow and components of the water budget for the pre-restoration period before 1996 and the restoration period from 1996 onward.

title: Hydrology
text:
The Trout Creek Watershed is located on the southern side of Lake Tahoe, California, adjacent to the Nevada state border (Figure 1). The main water features include Saxton Creek, Cold Creek, Trout Creek and Heavenly Valley Creek. These features converge into the main channel of Trout Creek, which flows north before draining into Lake Tahoe. The drainage area above the stream gauge is 36.7 square miles (Table 1).
The highest elevation of Trout Creek Watershed Is 10878 feet and the minimum elevation at the stream gauge is 6261 feet. The mean slope of the watershed is 30.1%, with steep, mountainous terrain in the southern region that becomes flatter toward the northern part as it nears the lake. The largest listed land cover type in the area is forest, which covers 43.1% of the watershed (Table 1). Urban land covers 3.1%, and lakes and ponds cover less than 1% of the area. Other land cover types are not specified by Web Soil Survey. Soils in the watershed are dominantly composed of various types of sand, including loamy, cobbly, coarse, gravelly, and stony sands, along with combinations of these textures (Table 2). They are primarily classified as excessively well-drained.

Table 1: Characteristics of the Trout Creek watershed.


Parameter Description
Value

minimum basin elevation

43.1 %


area covered by lakes and ponds
0.08881 %


area of developed (urban) land
3.1 %

title: Hydrology
text:
Discharge data for USGS-10336780, the Trout Creek stream gauge, spans water years 1961-2023. Precipitation, grass reference evapotranspiration, snow water equivalent, and soil moisture at a depth of 10-40 cm were downloaded from climateengine.org for water years 1981-2023. Precipitation and grass reference evapotranspiration trends are calculated from the dataset GridMET - 4km -daily. Snow water equivelent and soil moisture trends are calculated from the dataset WILDAS - 1.1 km - daily.


Code
# Create a table for the stream gauge
trout_creek_table <- tibble(site_no = '10336780', gauge = 'Trout Creek')

# Get data from USGS
trout_creek <- readNWISdv(
  siteNumber = trout_creek_table$site_no,
  parameterCd = '00060',
  startDate = "1960-10-01",
  endDate = "2024-09-30"
) %>%
  renameNWISColumns() %>%
  left_join(trout_creek_table, by = 'site_no') %>%
  select(-'Flow_cd')

# Convert discharge from cfs to mm/day (drainage area is 36.7 square miles)
trout_creek <- trout_creek %>%
  mutate(Q_mm = Flow * 86400 / 36.7 / 5280 / 5280 * 304.8)

# Calculate water years
trout_creek <- trout_creek %>%
  mutate(
    month = month(Date),
    wyear = if_else(month > 9, year(Date) + 1, year(Date))
  )

# Separate into periods to analyze: the pre-restoration period is before 1996.
# The restoration period is equal to and following 1996.
# Calculate annual totals for Q
Q_annual <- trout_creek %>%
  mutate(group = ifelse(wyear < 1996, "pre-restoration", "restoration")) %>%
  group_by(group, wyear) %>%
  summarize(Q_mm = sum(Q_mm), count = n())

# Graph annual discharge with a scatter plot
Q <- Q_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = wyear, y = Q_mm, color = group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "Annual Q (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

# Graph annual discharge with a box plot
Q_box <- Q_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = group, y = Q_mm, fill = group)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_bw() +
  labs(x = "", y = 'Q (mm)') +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(title = NULL))

# Graph annual discharge with a violin plot
Q_violin <- Q_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = group, y = Q_mm, fill = group)) +
  geom_violin() +
  theme_bw() +
  labs(x = "", y = 'Q (mm)') +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(title = NULL))

# Plot daily discharge
Q_daily <- trout_creek %>%
  mutate(group = ifelse(wyear < 1996, "pre-restoration", "restoration")) %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = wyear, y = Q_mm, color = group)) +
  geom_line() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "Daily Q (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

# Stitch plots together
ggarrange(Q_violin, Q_box, Q_daily, Q, ncol = 2, nrow = 2, common.legend = TRUE, legend = "bottom")





Figure 2: Annual, daily, and total sum discharge for Trout Creek for water years 1960-2023.




Discharge minimum, maximum, mean, and standard deviation are all higher in the restoration group than in the pre-restoration group, indicating greater discharge variability (Table 3). The restoration period saw the highest daily discharge on January 2, 1997, at 12.80 mm (Figure 2). The highest annual discharge occurred in 2017, totaling 152.80 mm. Discharge exceedance probability (p) shows slightly higher low and high flows in the restoration group compared to the pre-restoration group (Figures 3 & 4).
The watershed is semi-arid with an average annual precipitation of 895.91 mm and an aridity index (P/ET) of 0.79. The runoff ratio (Q/P) is 0.39, meaning that over half of precipitation does not become runoff. This could be due to evapotranspiration and the watershed’s excessively drained soils.


Code
#Calculate flow duration curve:
#exceedance probability (p) = rank/n+1
pre_restoration <- trout_creek %>%
  filter(wyear < 1996) %>%
  mutate(
    group='pre-restoration',
    rank=rank(Flow),
    p=rank/12784 
  )

restoration <- trout_creek %>%
  filter(wyear >= 1996) %>%
  mutate(
    group='restoration',
    rank=rank(Flow),
    p=rank/10594 
  )

fdc=rbind(pre_restoration,restoration)

#Plot fcd
fdc_plot <- fdc %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=p,y=Flow,color=group, linetype=group))+
  geom_line()+
  theme_bw()+
  labs(x = "Exceedance Probability (p)",y = "Flow (cfs)") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL),
         linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

ggplotly()




Figure 3: Discharge(Q) exceedance probability (p) for Trout Creek watershed for water years 1961-2023.




Code
#Plot fdc scale_y_log10() to better visualize data
#Optional: can put limits within the log; example: scale_y_log10(100,1000)
fdc_plot_log <- fdc %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=p,y=Flow,color=group, linetype=group))+
  scale_y_log10()+
  geom_line()+
  theme_bw()+
  labs(x = "Exceedance Probability (p)",y = "Flow (cfs) - Log 10") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL),
         linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

ggplotly()




Figure 4: Discharge(Q) exceedance probability (p) at Log 10 for Trout Creek watershed for water years 1961-2023.


Mean annual precipitation increased slightly from 888.26 mm pre-restoration to 899.96 mm in the restoration period. Mean annual discharge also increased slightly from 337.80 mm pre-restoration to 357.09 mm post-restoration. Mean annual evapotranspiration increased from 1083.18 mm pre-restoration to 1153.28 mm post-restoration. In contrast, both mean annual snow water equivalent and soil moisture decreased from the pre-restoration to the restoration group. Snow water equivalent dropped from 311.69 mm to 297.45 mm, and soil moisture dropped from 50.04 mm to 48.83 mm. Annual trends show that evapotranspiration increased, while soil moisture decreased from 1981 to 2023 (Figure 5).


Code
# Read CSV files for P, ET, SM, and SWE:
P_TC <- read.csv('data/TC_Precip_Gridmet.csv')
ET_TC <- read.csv('data/TC_ET_Gridmet.csv')
SM_TC <- read.csv('data/TC_SM_10_40_Wildas.csv')
SWE_TC <- read.csv('data/TC_SWE_Wildas.csv')

# Filter Q_1981 based on the year range
Q_1981 <- trout_creek %>%
  filter(wyear >= 1981 & wyear <= 2023)

# Convert Date Format
P_TC$Date = mdy(P_TC$Date)

# Join P_TC with Q_1981
P_TC <- P_TC %>%
  left_join(Q_1981 %>% select(Date, Q_mm, wyear), by = "Date")

# Bind Other Variables
P_TC$ET_mm = ET_TC$ET_mm
P_TC$SM_mm = SM_TC$SM_mm
P_TC$SWE_mm = SWE_TC$SWE_mm

#Separate Pre-restoration and Restoration Periods
TC_climate <- P_TC %>%
  mutate(
    group = case_when(
      wyear < 1996 ~ "pre-restoration",
      wyear >= 1996 ~ "restoration"))


#Calculate Annual Trends
climate_annual <- suppressMessages(TC_climate %>%
  group_by(wyear,group) %>%
  summarize(P_mm=sum(P_mm),
            Q_mm=sum(Q_mm),
            ET_mm=sum(ET_mm),
            peakSWE=max(SWE_mm),
            meanSM=mean(SM_mm),
            ))

#Plot Annual Sum Q
Q_1981 <- Q_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=Q_mm,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "Q (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Annual Sum P
P <- climate_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=P_mm,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "P (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Annual Sum ET
ET <- climate_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=ET_mm,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "ET (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Annual Peak SWE
SWE <- climate_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=peakSWE,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "SWE (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Annual Mean SM
SM <- climate_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=meanSM,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "SM (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

ggarrange(P,ET,SWE,SM,Q_1981, ncol=2,nrow=3, common.legend = TRUE, legend = "bottom")





Figure 5: Annual sum for precipitation(P), grass reference evapotranspiration(ET), and discharge (Q). Annual peak snow water equivalent(SWE). Annual mean soil moisture(SM). Values for water years 1980-2023.




Three notable years occurred: 1983, 2017, and 2021. In 1983, the watershed recorded the highest annual average soil moisture (54.59 mm) and the lowest annual average evapotranspiration (941.37 mm). In 2017, the watershed experienced the highest recorded annual discharge (1052.80 mm) and precipitation (1888.09 mm). In 2021, the watershed recorded the lowest annual soil moisture (42.91 mm) and the highest annual evapotranspiration (1250.37 mm). The Caldor Fire occurred during water years 2021 and 2022. Specifically, the Caldor Fire started on 8/14/2021 and was fully contained on 10/25/2021. Rain and snowmelt inputs were low from June to September of 2021, causing soil moisture to decline during that period (Figure 7). A precipitation event in mid-October of 2021 increased soil moisture and coincided with the containment of the fire.


Code
#Calculate monthly mean for P, Q, ET, SWE, and SM. For the flux variables P, Q and ET, calculate monthly sums before averaging: 
monthly_mean_flux <- suppressMessages(TC_climate %>%
  mutate(month=month(Date)) %>%
  group_by(month, group, wyear) %>%
  summarize(
    Q_mm_sum = sum(Q_mm),
    P_mm_sum = sum(P_mm),
    ET_mm_sum = sum(ET_mm)) %>%
   summarize(
    Q_mm = mean(Q_mm_sum),
    P_mm = mean(P_mm_sum),
    ET_mm = mean(ET_mm_sum)))

monthly_mean_stock <- suppressMessages(TC_climate %>%
  mutate(month=month(Date)) %>%
  group_by(month,group) %>%
  summarize(
    SWE_mm = mean(SWE_mm),
    SM_mm = mean(SM_mm)))

#Plot Mean Monthly SWE
SWE_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_stock %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = month, y = SWE_mm, color = group, linetype = group)) + 
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "SWE (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group")

#Plot Mean Monthly ET
ET_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_flux %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = month, y = ET_mm, color = group, linetype = group)) + 
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "ET (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL), linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Mean Monthly SM
SM_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_stock %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = month, y = SM_mm, color = group, linetype = group)) + 
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "SM (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL), linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Mean Monthly P
P_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_flux %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = month, y = P_mm, color = group, linetype = group)) + 
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "P (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL), linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Mean Monthly Q
Q_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_flux %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=month,y=Q_mm,color=group, linetype = group)) +
  geom_line()+
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "Q (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL), linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

ggarrange(
  P_mean_plot, ET_mean_plot, Q_mean_plot, SM_mean_plot, SWE_mean_plot, 
  ncol = 2, nrow = 3,
  common.legend = TRUE,  
  legend = "bottom")





Figure 6: Monthly averages for Trout Creek watershed for water years 1961 – 2023. Mean monthly sums for precipitation(P), grass reference evapotranspiration(ET), and discharge (Q). Mean monthly snow water equivalent(SWE) and soil moisture(SM).




Monthly trends show that precipitation is elevated from October through April, with a decline from May through September (Figure 6). Snow accumulates during winter, with snowmelt typically occurring between April and July. Soil moisture decreases during the spring and summer months, continuing through August and September, before increasing with higher precipitation in winter. Discharge peaks from March through August, typically in May or June. Evapotranspiration is lowest in December and January, gradually increasing and peaking in July, before gradually declining. Evapotranspiration rises in warmer months and declines in the winter months.

Table 3: Annual mean, maximum, minimum, and standard deviation for discharge (Q) of Trout Creek for the pre-restoration period (water years 1961-1995) and restoration period (1996-2023).


Period
Max Q
Min Q
Standard Deviation


Pre restoration
801.80
95.88
182.50


Restoration
1052.80
108.22
240.12





Code
#Closer Look at the Caldor Fire
caldor <- TC_climate %>%
  filter(wyear==2021 | wyear==2022) 

#Separate Snowmelt and Rain from P
caldor$rain=ifelse(caldor$SWE_mm==0,caldor$P_mm,0)
caldor$snowmelt=0

for (i in 2:730) {
  caldor[i, 'snowmelt'] <- ifelse(caldor[i, 'SWE_mm'] < caldor[i-1, 'SWE_mm'], caldor[i-1, 'SWE_mm'] - caldor[i, 'SWE_mm'], 0)
}

#Plot Rain, Snowmelt, and soil Moisture
caldor_plot <- caldor %>%
  ggplot() +
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = Date, y = SM_mm, color = "SM (mm)")) +   
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = Date, y = rain, color = "Rain (mm/day)")) +     
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = Date, y = snowmelt, color = "Snowmelt (mm/day)")) + 
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = Date, y = ET_mm, color = "ET (mm/day)")) +
  theme_bw()+
  labs(y = "",color = "Legend") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))+
  scale_x_date(
    breaks = "4 month",
    labels = scales::date_format("%b %Y"))

ggplotly()




Figure 7: Rain, snowmelt, and soil moisture depth in mm for water years 2021 and 2022 (10/01/2020 – 9/30/2022) for Trout Creek watershed.

title: Trout Creek Watershed
text:
Figures


Code
# Create a table for the stream gauge
trout_creek_table <- tibble(site_no = '10336780', gauge = 'Trout Creek')

# Get data from USGS
trout_creek <- readNWISdv(
  siteNumber = trout_creek_table$site_no,
  parameterCd = '00060',
  startDate = "1960-10-01",
  endDate = "2024-09-30"
) %>%
  renameNWISColumns() %>%
  left_join(trout_creek_table, by = 'site_no') %>%
  select(-'Flow_cd')

# Convert discharge from cfs to mm/day (drainage area is 36.7 square miles)
trout_creek <- trout_creek %>%
  mutate(Q_mm = Flow * 86400 / 36.7 / 5280 / 5280 * 304.8)

# Calculate water years
trout_creek <- trout_creek %>%
  mutate(
    month = month(Date),
    wyear = if_else(month > 9, year(Date) + 1, year(Date))
  )

# Separate into periods to analyze: the pre-restoration period is before 1996.
# The restoration period is equal to and following 1996.
# Calculate annual totals for Q
Q_annual <- trout_creek %>%
  mutate(group = ifelse(wyear < 1996, "pre-restoration", "restoration")) %>%
  group_by(group, wyear) %>%
  summarize(Q_mm = sum(Q_mm), count = n())

# Graph annual discharge with a scatter plot
Q <- Q_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = wyear, y = Q_mm, color = group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "Annual Q (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

# Graph annual discharge with a box plot
Q_box <- Q_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = group, y = Q_mm, fill = group)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_bw() +
  labs(x = "", y = 'Q (mm)') +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(title = NULL))

# Graph annual discharge with a violin plot
Q_violin <- Q_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = group, y = Q_mm, fill = group)) +
  geom_violin() +
  theme_bw() +
  labs(x = "", y = 'Q (mm)') +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(title = NULL))

# Plot daily discharge
Q_daily <- trout_creek %>%
  mutate(group = ifelse(wyear < 1996, "pre-restoration", "restoration")) %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = wyear, y = Q_mm, color = group)) +
  geom_line() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "Daily Q (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

# Stitch plots together
ggarrange(Q_violin, Q_box, Q_daily, Q, ncol = 2, nrow = 2, common.legend = TRUE, legend = "bottom")





Figure 2: Annual, daily, and total sum discharge for Trout Creek for water years 1960-2023.






Code
#Calculate flow duration curve:
#exceedance probability (p) = rank/n+1
pre_restoration <- trout_creek %>%
  filter(wyear < 1996) %>%
  mutate(
    group='pre-restoration',
    rank=rank(Flow),
    p=rank/12784 
  )

restoration <- trout_creek %>%
  filter(wyear >= 1996) %>%
  mutate(
    group='restoration',
    rank=rank(Flow),
    p=rank/10594 
  )

fdc=rbind(pre_restoration,restoration)

#Plot fcd
fdc_plot <- fdc %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=p,y=Flow,color=group, linetype=group))+
  geom_line()+
  theme_bw()+
  labs(x = "Exceedance Probability (p)",y = "Flow (cfs)") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL),
         linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

ggplotly()




Figure 3: Discharge(Q) exceedance probability (p) for Trout Creek watershed for water years 1961-2023.




Code
#Plot fdc scale_y_log10() to better visualize data
#Optional: can put limits within the log; example: scale_y_log10(100,1000)
fdc_plot_log <- fdc %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=p,y=Flow,color=group, linetype=group))+
  scale_y_log10()+
  geom_line()+
  theme_bw()+
  labs(x = "Exceedance Probability (p)",y = "Flow (cfs) - Log 10") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL),
         linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

ggplotly()




Figure 4: Discharge(Q) exceedance probability (p) at Log 10 for Trout Creek watershed for water years 1961-2023.




Code
# Read CSV files for P, ET, SM, and SWE:
P_TC <- read.csv('data/TC_Precip_Gridmet.csv')
ET_TC <- read.csv('data/TC_ET_Gridmet.csv')
SM_TC <- read.csv('data/TC_SM_10_40_Wildas.csv')
SWE_TC <- read.csv('data/TC_SWE_Wildas.csv')

# Filter Q_1981 based on the year range
Q_1981 <- trout_creek %>%
  filter(wyear >= 1981 & wyear <= 2023)

# Convert Date Format
P_TC$Date = mdy(P_TC$Date)

# Join P_TC with Q_1981
P_TC <- P_TC %>%
  left_join(Q_1981 %>% select(Date, Q_mm, wyear), by = "Date")

# Bind Other Variables
P_TC$ET_mm = ET_TC$ET_mm
P_TC$SM_mm = SM_TC$SM_mm
P_TC$SWE_mm = SWE_TC$SWE_mm

#Separate Pre-restoration and Restoration Periods
TC_climate <- P_TC %>%
  mutate(
    group = case_when(
      wyear < 1996 ~ "pre-restoration",
      wyear >= 1996 ~ "restoration"))


#Calculate Annual Trends
climate_annual <- suppressMessages(TC_climate %>%
  group_by(wyear,group) %>%
  summarize(P_mm=sum(P_mm),
            Q_mm=sum(Q_mm),
            ET_mm=sum(ET_mm),
            peakSWE=max(SWE_mm),
            meanSM=mean(SM_mm),
            ))

#Plot Annual Sum Q
Q_1981 <- Q_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=Q_mm,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "Q (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Annual Sum P
P <- climate_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=P_mm,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "P (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Annual Sum ET
ET <- climate_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=ET_mm,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "ET (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Annual Peak SWE
SWE <- climate_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=peakSWE,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "SWE (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Annual Mean SM
SM <- climate_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=meanSM,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "SM (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

ggarrange(P,ET,SWE,SM,Q_1981, ncol=2,nrow=3, common.legend = TRUE, legend = "bottom")





Figure 5: Annual sum for precipitation(P), grass reference evapotranspiration(ET), and discharge (Q). Annual peak snow water equivalent(SWE). Annual mean soil moisture(SM). Values for water years 1980-2023.






Code
#Calculate monthly mean for P, Q, ET, SWE, and SM. For the flux variables P, Q and ET, calculate monthly sums before averaging: 
monthly_mean_flux <- suppressMessages(TC_climate %>%
  mutate(month=month(Date)) %>%
  group_by(month, group, wyear) %>%
  summarize(
    Q_mm_sum = sum(Q_mm),
    P_mm_sum = sum(P_mm),
    ET_mm_sum = sum(ET_mm)) %>%
   summarize(
    Q_mm = mean(Q_mm_sum),
    P_mm = mean(P_mm_sum),
    ET_mm = mean(ET_mm_sum)))

monthly_mean_stock <- suppressMessages(TC_climate %>%
  mutate(month=month(Date)) %>%
  group_by(month,group) %>%
  summarize(
    SWE_mm = mean(SWE_mm),
    SM_mm = mean(SM_mm)))

#Plot Mean Monthly SWE
SWE_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_stock %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = month, y = SWE_mm, color = group, linetype = group)) + 
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "SWE (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group")

#Plot Mean Monthly ET
ET_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_flux %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = month, y = ET_mm, color = group, linetype = group)) + 
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "ET (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL), linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Mean Monthly SM
SM_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_stock %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = month, y = SM_mm, color = group, linetype = group)) + 
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "SM (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL), linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Mean Monthly P
P_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_flux %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = month, y = P_mm, color = group, linetype = group)) + 
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "P (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL), linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Mean Monthly Q
Q_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_flux %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=month,y=Q_mm,color=group, linetype = group)) +
  geom_line()+
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "Q (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL), linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

ggarrange(
  P_mean_plot, ET_mean_plot, Q_mean_plot, SM_mean_plot, SWE_mean_plot, 
  ncol = 2, nrow = 3,
  common.legend = TRUE,  
  legend = "bottom")





Figure 6: Monthly averages for Trout Creek watershed for water years 1961 – 2023. Mean monthly sums for precipitation(P), grass reference evapotranspiration(ET), and discharge (Q). Mean monthly snow water equivalent(SWE) and soil moisture(SM).






Code
#Closer Look at the Caldor Fire
caldor <- TC_climate %>%
  filter(wyear==2021 | wyear==2022) 

#Separate Snowmelt and Rain from P
caldor$rain=ifelse(caldor$SWE_mm==0,caldor$P_mm,0)
caldor$snowmelt=0

for (i in 2:730) {
  caldor[i, 'snowmelt'] <- ifelse(caldor[i, 'SWE_mm'] < caldor[i-1, 'SWE_mm'], caldor[i-1, 'SWE_mm'] - caldor[i, 'SWE_mm'], 0)
}

#Plot Rain, Snowmelt, and soil Moisture
caldor_plot <- caldor %>%
  ggplot() +
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = Date, y = SM_mm, color = "SM (mm)")) +   
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = Date, y = rain, color = "Rain (mm/day)")) +     
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = Date, y = snowmelt, color = "Snowmelt (mm/day)")) + 
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = Date, y = ET_mm, color = "ET (mm/day)")) +
  theme_bw()+
  labs(y = "",color = "Legend") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))+
  scale_x_date(
    breaks = "4 month",
    labels = scales::date_format("%b %Y"))

ggplotly()




Figure 7: Rain, snowmelt, and soil moisture depth in mm for water years 2021 and 2022 (10/01/2020 – 9/30/2022) for Trout Creek watershed.

title: Hydrology
text: The restoration period shows increased variability in discharge compared to the pre-restoration period. This change appears to correlate more strongly with variations in precipitation than with the restoration efforts. Seasonal and annual trends suggest that precipitation and snowpack strongly influence streamflow. The observed increases in average precipitation, discharge and reference evapotranspiration, coupled with decreases in snow water equivalent and soil moisture suggest that climate variability may be driving hydrologic changes in the watershed. The most prominent trends from water years 1981 through 2023 are the consistent decrease in soil moisture and the increase in reference evapotranspiration, indicating increasing aridity in the watershed. Additionally, greater climatic variability is observed during the restoration period, with both higher and lower precipitation values, which contribute to increased fluctuations in snow water equivalent and discharge. These patterns may be influenced by more dramatic climate-driven weather patterns, which may amplify seasonal and annual variability in hydraulic conditions of Trout Creek watershed. Record high annual evapotranspiration and low soil moisture correlate to the Caldor fire, which burned through parts of the watershed in 2021.

title: Hydrology
text:
California Tahoe Conservancy. (2022). Greater Upper Truckee Watershed Restoration Accomplishments and Opportunities. https://tahoe.ca.gov/programs/water-quality-watersheds/
TRCD. (2013). Conservation Projects and Environmental Improvement Projects (EIPs) in the Trout-Cold Creek Community Watershed. Tahoe Resource Conservation District. https://tahoercd.org
ClimateEngine.org. (2024). https://www.climateengine.org
USGS. (2024). StreamStats. https://streamstats.usgs.gov/ss/
USDA. (2024). Web Soil Survey. https://websoilsurvey.sc.egov.usda.gov/App/WebSoilSurvey.aspx

title: Colleen Hoskins
text: I’m a graduate student at Colorado State University studying water resources and data analysis. I work for the ROSSyndicate managing a database of water sources across U.S. National Parks. I spend my days investigating, mapping, and compiling records of surface and groundwater sources available to park visitors and staff. Before attending CSU, I worked in environmental conservation, where I led field crews, conducted ecosystem monitoring, and researched methods to prevent the spread of aquatic invasive weeds. I am interested in using data science to support water resources research and management.

text: Focus: Water Resources and Data Analytics

title: Resume

EXPERIENCE

COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY - ROSSyndicate | Fort Collins, CO

Water Database Specialist | January 2025 – Present

Developing a geospatial database of water supplies for all US National Parks
Researching, digitizing, and visualizing water resources data using Excel, R and GIS
Supporting research to evaluate the security of National Park water supplies




EASTERN NEVADA LANDSCAPE COALITION | Carson City, NV; Elko, NV

Weeds Crew Lead | June 2023 - September 2023


Ecological Monitoring Crew Lead | April 2019 - October 2019
Leadership - Led a weeds crew in surveying, inventorying, monitoring, and treating 3,700+ acres of public BLM land, developing treatment plans based on weed type, plant growth stage and infestation severity to reduce invasive species and support native ecosystems - Led an AIM crew in assessing, inventorying, and monitoring 100+ plots on BLM rangelands of Eastern Nevada to evaluate land health, post-wildfire rehabilitation efforts and wildlife habitat
Mapping and Data Management - Mapped and photographed invasive species using GIS, Field Maps and Survey 123, generating spatial data to inform land management strategies - Analyzed field data and maintained data quality by inputting and verifying information into a DIMA database (Microsoft Access), ensuring the accuracy of long-term ecological monitoring records



TKPOA | South Lake Tahoe, CA

Water Quality Intern | April 2021 - November 2021


Water Quality Technician | April 2022 - June 2022

Collected water quality data from 70 locations at 5 depths in the water column using YSI ProDSS and OTT Hydromet HL4 Sonde devices to assess the effect of invasive weeds on water quality
Mapped 172 acres of waterways monthly during the plant growth season using boats equipped with sonar to visualize plant density Monitored floating plant fragments daily to track species percentages and collected 60+ cubic feet of weed fragments over 80 days




HEAVENLY SKI RESORT | South Lake Tahoe, CA

Ski Instructor | November - April, 2020 - 2024

Taught fundamental ski skills while promoting slope etiquette, mountain safety, and teamwork
Created a fun learning environment to encourage students to develop a lifelong passion for winter sports Organized students into classes based on skill level and assigned ski instructors to each class

title: Data Science Labs
text:
COVID Trends





Weighted mean center of the COVID-19 outbreak




Through this lab, I developed skills in vector data analysis and visualization using COVID-19 data. I gained experience in data wrangling with dplyr, tidyverse, and lubridate; data visualization with ggplot2 and flextable; and building and evaluating a linear model. I also used sf and zoo for spatial and temporal data analysis.
View the lab here: Lab 1 - COVID Trends

title: Data Science
text:
Lab 1 - COVID Trends
The focus of this lab was vector data analysis and visualization using COVID-19 data. Key stills include data wrangling with dplyr, tidyverse, and lubridate; visualization with ggplot2 and flextable; and linear model building and evaluation. The lab also uses sf and zoo to analyze spatial and temporal data.









View the entire lab here: Lab 1 - COVID Trends
Lab 2
Lab 3
Lab 4

title: Data Science Labs
text:
Distances and Projections





Map of major cities within 100 miles of the U.S. border




In this lab, I continued to build on my vector data wrangling and visualization skills. I explored the structure and properties of sf, sfc, and sfg objects, and used the sf package to work with spatial data. I practiced transforming coordinate reference systems, calculating distances, and handling spatial geometries. Additionally, I expanded my data visualization techniques using mapview and gglighlight.
View the lab here: Lab 2 - Distances and Projections

title: Data Science Labs
text:
Tessallations, Point-in-Polygon





Distribution of Hydroelectric Dams across the USA with Hexagonal Grid Tessallation (above mean + 1 standard deviations)




By completing this lab, I learned how to implement tessellations for spatial data analysis and learned about the Modifiable Areal Unit Problem (MAUP). I used the AOI package to define an area of interest encompassing CONUS states. I then used Voronoi, triangulated, square grid, and hexagonal grid tessellations to examine the spatial distribution of US dams. I used point-in-polygon analysis and rmapshaper to simplify geometries, and wrote functions to streamline analysis and visualization. Adding to my data visualization skills, I created an interactive map using leaflet and used kableExtra to create a polished table.
View the lab here: Lab 3 - Tessallations, Point-in-Polygon

title: Data Science Labs
text:
Rasters & Remote Sensing





Staellite imagery raster layers of 5 indices for Palo, Iowa during the flooding event on September 26, 2016)




In this lab, I practiced working with raster data by creating flood maps using satellite imagery from a flooding event along the Cedar and Wapsipinicon rivers. I used terra and rstac to access and process Landsat Collection 2 imagery, and then RGB composites for initial visualization. Using raster algebra, I calculated spectral indices, applied thresholds, and used the stats package to extract flood clusters. I then categorized flood extent and classified flood certainty.
View the lab here: Lab 4 - Raster & Remote Sensing

title: Data Science Labs
text:
Machine Learning in Hydrology





Random Forest Model Using PET and Precipitation to Predict Streamflow




Through this lab, I explored predictive modeling using the tidymodels framework and the Catchment Attributes and Meteorology for Large-samples Studies (CAMELS) dataset. I learned best practices for building reproducable models. I applied and compared four modeling techniques: linear regression, random forest, xgboost and neural networks using baguette. I evaluated model performance using RMSE, R-squared, and MAE, and visualized results using the vipand workflows packages.
View the lab here: Lab 5 - Machine Learning in Hydrology

title: Trout Creek Watershed Analysis
text: Figure 1: Map of Trout Creek watershed boundary and location of stream gauge USGS-10336790.

title: Trout Creek Watershed Analysis
text:
Introduction
Trout Creek was historically one of the most productive fisheries in the Tahoe Basin. In 1859, logging began in the Trout Creek Area. During the logging period, 13 miles of railroad, 16 miles of wagon haul roads, 2 miles of “V” flume and 28 logging camps were constructed in the Trout Creek watershed, causing erosion along Trout Creek and Saxton Creek (TRCD, 2013). Post-logging, the Trout Creek watershed was used to graze cattle and sheep. During this time, a ditch system and a series of small dams were developed along the tributaries of Trout Creek and Cold Creek (TRCD, 2013). Excessive grazing degraded watershed conditions. In 1996, the dams were removed from Cold Creek (California Tahoe Conservancy, 2022). Since 1996, projects within the Trout Creek watershed were conducted to restore the watershed to its historic condition. In 2021, the Caldor Fire burned areas within the Trout Creek Watershed, affecting the watershed’s streams (California Tahoe Conservancy, 2022). Moving forward, plans are being developed for restoration projects in several sections of Trout Creek and Cold Creek.  
This analysis compares flow and components of the water budget for the pre-restoration period before 1996 and the restoration period from 1996 onward.

title: Trout Creek Watershed Analysis
text:
Watershed Characteristics
The Trout Creek Watershed is located on the southern side of Lake Tahoe, California, adjacent to the Nevada state border (Figure 1). The main water features include Saxton Creek, Cold Creek, Trout Creek and Heavenly Valley Creek. These features converge into the main channel of Trout Creek, which flows north before draining into Lake Tahoe. The drainage area above the stream gauge is 36.7 square miles (Table 1).
The highest elevation of Trout Creek Watershed Is 10878 feet and the minimum elevation at the stream gauge is 6261 feet. The mean slope of the watershed is 30.1%, with steep, mountainous terrain in the southern region that becomes flatter toward the northern part as it nears the lake. The largest listed land cover type in the area is forest, which covers 43.1% of the watershed (Table 1). Urban land covers 3.1%, and lakes and ponds cover less than 1% of the area. Other land cover types are not specified by Web Soil Survey. Soils in the watershed are dominantly composed of various types of sand, including loamy, cobbly, coarse, gravelly, and stony sands, along with combinations of these textures (Table 2). They are primarily classified as excessively well-drained.

Table 1: Characteristics of the Trout Creek watershed.

title: Trout Creek Watershed Analysis
text:
Watershed Analysis
Discharge data for USGS-10336780, the Trout Creek stream gauge, spans water years 1961-2023. Precipitation, grass reference evapotranspiration, snow water equivalent, and soil moisture at a depth of 10-40 cm were downloaded from climateengine.org for water years 1981-2023. Precipitation and grass reference evapotranspiration trends are calculated from the dataset GridMET - 4km -daily. Snow water equivelent and soil moisture trends are calculated from the dataset WILDAS - 1.1 km - daily.


Code
# Create a table for the stream gauge
trout_creek_table <- tibble(site_no = '10336780', gauge = 'Trout Creek')

# Get data from USGS
trout_creek <- readNWISdv(
  siteNumber = trout_creek_table$site_no,
  parameterCd = '00060',
  startDate = "1960-10-01",
  endDate = "2024-09-30"
) %>%
  renameNWISColumns() %>%
  left_join(trout_creek_table, by = 'site_no') %>%
  select(-'Flow_cd')

# Convert discharge from cfs to mm/day (drainage area is 36.7 square miles)
trout_creek <- trout_creek %>%
  mutate(Q_mm = Flow * 86400 / 36.7 / 5280 / 5280 * 304.8)

# Calculate water years
trout_creek <- trout_creek %>%
  mutate(
    month = month(Date),
    wyear = if_else(month > 9, year(Date) + 1, year(Date))
  )

# Separate into periods to analyze: the pre-restoration period is before 1996.
# The restoration period is equal to and following 1996.
# Calculate annual totals for Q
Q_annual <- trout_creek %>%
  mutate(group = ifelse(wyear < 1996, "pre-restoration", "restoration")) %>%
  group_by(group, wyear) %>%
  summarize(Q_mm = sum(Q_mm), count = n())

# Graph annual discharge with a scatter plot
Q <- Q_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = wyear, y = Q_mm, color = group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "Annual Q (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

# Graph annual discharge with a box plot
Q_box <- Q_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = group, y = Q_mm, fill = group)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_bw() +
  labs(x = "", y = 'Q (mm)') +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(title = NULL))

# Graph annual discharge with a violin plot
Q_violin <- Q_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = group, y = Q_mm, fill = group)) +
  geom_violin() +
  theme_bw() +
  labs(x = "", y = 'Q (mm)') +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(title = NULL))

# Plot daily discharge
Q_daily <- trout_creek %>%
  mutate(group = ifelse(wyear < 1996, "pre-restoration", "restoration")) %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = wyear, y = Q_mm, color = group)) +
  geom_line() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "Daily Q (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

# Stitch plots together
ggarrange(Q_violin, Q_box, Q_daily, Q, ncol = 2, nrow = 2, common.legend = TRUE, legend = "bottom")





Figure 2: Annual, daily, and total sum discharge for Trout Creek for water years 1960-2023.




Discharge minimum, maximum, mean, and standard deviation are all higher in the restoration group than in the pre-restoration group, indicating greater discharge variability (Table 3). The restoration period saw the highest daily discharge on January 2, 1997, at 12.80 mm (Figure 2). The highest annual discharge occurred in 2017, totaling 152.80 mm. Discharge exceedance probability (p) shows slightly higher low and high flows in the restoration group compared to the pre-restoration group (Figures 3 & 4).
The watershed is semi-arid with an average annual precipitation of 895.91 mm and an aridity index (P/ET) of 0.79. The runoff ratio (Q/P) is 0.39, meaning that over half of precipitation does not become runoff. This could be due to evapotranspiration and the watershed’s excessively drained soils.


Code
#Calculate flow duration curve:
#exceedance probability (p) = rank/n+1
pre_restoration <- trout_creek %>%
  filter(wyear < 1996) %>%
  mutate(
    group='pre-restoration',
    rank=rank(Flow),
    p=rank/12784 
  )

restoration <- trout_creek %>%
  filter(wyear >= 1996) %>%
  mutate(
    group='restoration',
    rank=rank(Flow),
    p=rank/10594 
  )

fdc=rbind(pre_restoration,restoration)

#Plot fcd
fdc_plot <- fdc %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=p,y=Flow,color=group, linetype=group))+
  geom_line()+
  theme_bw()+
  labs(x = "Exceedance Probability (p)",y = "Flow (cfs)") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL),
         linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

ggplotly()




Figure 3: Discharge(Q) exceedance probability (p) for Trout Creek watershed for water years 1961-2023.




Code
#Plot fdc scale_y_log10() to better visualize data
#Optional: can put limits within the log; example: scale_y_log10(100,1000)
fdc_plot_log <- fdc %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=p,y=Flow,color=group, linetype=group))+
  scale_y_log10()+
  geom_line()+
  theme_bw()+
  labs(x = "Exceedance Probability (p)",y = "Flow (cfs) - Log 10") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL),
         linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

ggplotly()




Figure 4: Discharge(Q) exceedance probability (p) at Log 10 for Trout Creek watershed for water years 1961-2023.


Mean annual precipitation increased slightly from 888.26 mm pre-restoration to 899.96 mm in the restoration period. Mean annual discharge also increased slightly from 337.80 mm pre-restoration to 357.09 mm post-restoration. Mean annual evapotranspiration increased from 1083.18 mm pre-restoration to 1153.28 mm post-restoration. In contrast, both mean annual snow water equivalent and soil moisture decreased from the pre-restoration to the restoration group. Snow water equivalent dropped from 311.69 mm to 297.45 mm, and soil moisture dropped from 50.04 mm to 48.83 mm. Annual trends show that evapotranspiration increased, while soil moisture decreased from 1981 to 2023 (Figure 5).


Code
# Read CSV files for P, ET, SM, and SWE:
P_TC <- read.csv('data/TC_Precip_Gridmet.csv')
ET_TC <- read.csv('data/TC_ET_Gridmet.csv')
SM_TC <- read.csv('data/TC_SM_10_40_Wildas.csv')
SWE_TC <- read.csv('data/TC_SWE_Wildas.csv')

# Filter Q_1981 based on the year range
Q_1981 <- trout_creek %>%
  filter(wyear >= 1981 & wyear <= 2023)

# Convert Date Format
P_TC$Date = mdy(P_TC$Date)

# Join P_TC with Q_1981
P_TC <- P_TC %>%
  left_join(Q_1981 %>% select(Date, Q_mm, wyear), by = "Date")

# Bind Other Variables
P_TC$ET_mm = ET_TC$ET_mm
P_TC$SM_mm = SM_TC$SM_mm
P_TC$SWE_mm = SWE_TC$SWE_mm

#Separate Pre-restoration and Restoration Periods
TC_climate <- P_TC %>%
  mutate(
    group = case_when(
      wyear < 1996 ~ "pre-restoration",
      wyear >= 1996 ~ "restoration"))


#Calculate Annual Trends
climate_annual <- suppressMessages(TC_climate %>%
  group_by(wyear,group) %>%
  summarize(P_mm=sum(P_mm),
            Q_mm=sum(Q_mm),
            ET_mm=sum(ET_mm),
            peakSWE=max(SWE_mm),
            meanSM=mean(SM_mm),
            ))

#Plot Annual Sum Q
Q_1981 <- Q_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=Q_mm,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "Q (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Annual Sum P
P <- climate_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=P_mm,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "P (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Annual Sum ET
ET <- climate_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=ET_mm,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "ET (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Annual Peak SWE
SWE <- climate_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=peakSWE,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "SWE (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Annual Mean SM
SM <- climate_annual %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=wyear,y=meanSM,color=group)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Water Year", y = "SM (mm)", color = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))

ggarrange(P,ET,SWE,SM,Q_1981, ncol=2,nrow=3, common.legend = TRUE, legend = "bottom")





Figure 5: Annual sum for precipitation(P), grass reference evapotranspiration(ET), and discharge (Q). Annual peak snow water equivalent(SWE). Annual mean soil moisture(SM). Values for water years 1980-2023.




Three notable years occurred: 1983, 2017, and 2021. In 1983, the watershed recorded the highest annual average soil moisture (54.59 mm) and the lowest annual average evapotranspiration (941.37 mm). In 2017, the watershed experienced the highest recorded annual discharge (1052.80 mm) and precipitation (1888.09 mm). In 2021, the watershed recorded the lowest annual soil moisture (42.91 mm) and the highest annual evapotranspiration (1250.37 mm). The Caldor Fire occurred during water years 2021 and 2022. Specifically, the Caldor Fire started on 8/14/2021 and was fully contained on 10/25/2021. Rain and snowmelt inputs were low from June to September of 2021, causing soil moisture to decline during that period (Figure 7). A precipitation event in mid-October of 2021 increased soil moisture and coincided with the containment of the fire.


Code
#Calculate monthly mean for P, Q, ET, SWE, and SM. For the flux variables P, Q and ET, calculate monthly sums before averaging: 
monthly_mean_flux <- suppressMessages(TC_climate %>%
  mutate(month=month(Date)) %>%
  group_by(month, group, wyear) %>%
  summarize(
    Q_mm_sum = sum(Q_mm),
    P_mm_sum = sum(P_mm),
    ET_mm_sum = sum(ET_mm)) %>%
   summarize(
    Q_mm = mean(Q_mm_sum),
    P_mm = mean(P_mm_sum),
    ET_mm = mean(ET_mm_sum)))

monthly_mean_stock <- suppressMessages(TC_climate %>%
  mutate(month=month(Date)) %>%
  group_by(month,group) %>%
  summarize(
    SWE_mm = mean(SWE_mm),
    SM_mm = mean(SM_mm)))

#Plot Mean Monthly SWE
SWE_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_stock %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = month, y = SWE_mm, color = group, linetype = group)) + 
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "SWE (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group")

#Plot Mean Monthly ET
ET_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_flux %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = month, y = ET_mm, color = group, linetype = group)) + 
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "ET (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL), linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Mean Monthly SM
SM_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_stock %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = month, y = SM_mm, color = group, linetype = group)) + 
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "SM (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL), linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Mean Monthly P
P_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_flux %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = month, y = P_mm, color = group, linetype = group)) + 
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "P (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL), linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

#Plot Mean Monthly Q
Q_mean_plot <- monthly_mean_flux %>%
  ggplot(mapping=aes(x=month,y=Q_mm,color=group, linetype = group)) +
  geom_line()+
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Month", y = "Q (mm)", color = "Group", linetype = "Group") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL), linetype = guide_legend(title = NULL))

ggarrange(
  P_mean_plot, ET_mean_plot, Q_mean_plot, SM_mean_plot, SWE_mean_plot, 
  ncol = 2, nrow = 3,
  common.legend = TRUE,  
  legend = "bottom")





Figure 6: Monthly averages for Trout Creek watershed for water years 1961 – 2023. Mean monthly sums for precipitation(P), grass reference evapotranspiration(ET), and discharge (Q). Mean monthly snow water equivalent(SWE) and soil moisture(SM).




Monthly trends show that precipitation is elevated from October through April, with a decline from May through September (Figure 6). Snow accumulates during winter, with snowmelt typically occurring between April and July. Soil moisture decreases during the spring and summer months, continuing through August and September, before increasing with higher precipitation in winter. Discharge peaks from March through August, typically in May or June. Evapotranspiration is lowest in December and January, gradually increasing and peaking in July, before gradually declining. Evapotranspiration rises in warmer months and declines in the winter months.

Table 3: Annual mean, maximum, minimum, and standard deviation for discharge (Q) of Trout Creek for the pre-restoration period (water years 1961-1995) and restoration period (1996-2023).

Code
#Closer Look at the Caldor Fire
caldor <- TC_climate %>%
  filter(wyear==2021 | wyear==2022) 

#Separate Snowmelt and Rain from P
caldor$rain=ifelse(caldor$SWE_mm==0,caldor$P_mm,0)
caldor$snowmelt=0

for (i in 2:730) {
  caldor[i, 'snowmelt'] <- ifelse(caldor[i, 'SWE_mm'] < caldor[i-1, 'SWE_mm'], caldor[i-1, 'SWE_mm'] - caldor[i, 'SWE_mm'], 0)
}

#Plot Rain, Snowmelt, and soil Moisture
caldor_plot <- caldor %>%
  ggplot() +
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = Date, y = SM_mm, color = "SM (mm)")) +   
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = Date, y = rain, color = "Rain (mm/day)")) +     
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = Date, y = snowmelt, color = "Snowmelt (mm/day)")) + 
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = Date, y = ET_mm, color = "ET (mm/day)")) +
  theme_bw()+
  labs(y = "",color = "Legend") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(title = NULL))+
  scale_x_date(
    breaks = "4 month",
    labels = scales::date_format("%b %Y"))

ggplotly()




Figure 7: Rain, snowmelt, and soil moisture depth in mm for water years 2021 and 2022 (10/01/2020 – 9/30/2022) for Trout Creek watershed.

title: Trout Creek Watershed Analysis
text:
Conclusions
The restoration period shows increased variability in discharge compared to the pre-restoration period. This change appears to correlate more strongly with variations in precipitation than with the restoration efforts. Seasonal and annual trends suggest that precipitation and snowpack strongly influence streamflow. The observed increases in average precipitation, discharge and reference evapotranspiration, coupled with decreases in snow water equivalent and soil moisture suggest that climate variability may be driving hydrologic changes in the watershed. The most prominent trends from water years 1981 through 2023 are the consistent decrease in soil moisture and the increase in reference evapotranspiration, indicating increasing aridity in the watershed. Additionally, greater climatic variability is observed during the restoration period, with both higher and lower precipitation values, which contribute to increased fluctuations in snow water equivalent and discharge. These patterns may be influenced by more dramatic climate-driven weather patterns, which may amplify seasonal and annual variability in hydraulic conditions of Trout Creek watershed. Record high annual evapotranspiration and low soil moisture correlate to the Caldor fire, which burned through parts of the watershed in 2021.

title: Trout Creek Watershed Analysis
text:
Sources
California Tahoe Conservancy. (2022). Greater Upper Truckee Watershed Restoration Accomplishments and Opportunities. https://tahoe.ca.gov/programs/water-quality-watersheds/
TRCD. (2013). Conservation Projects and Environmental Improvement Projects (EIPs) in the Trout-Cold Creek Community Watershed. Tahoe Resource Conservation District. https://tahoercd.org
ClimateEngine.org. (2024). https://www.climateengine.org
USGS. (2024). StreamStats. https://streamstats.usgs.gov/ss/
USDA. (2024). Web Soil Survey. https://websoilsurvey.sc.egov.usda.gov/App/WebSoilSurvey.aspx

title: Projects
text:
Trout Creek Watershed Analysis


This project examines the hydrology of the Trout Creek watershed, located on the southern side of Lake Tahoe, CA for water years 1960-2023. Using datasets from USGS and climateengine.org, I analyzed water budget components including precipitation, evapotranspiration, snow water equivalent, and soil moisture. The analysis compares pre- and post-restoration periods of the watershed, with results visualized using the R packages ggplot2, tmap, and plotly.
View the project here: Trout Creek Watershed Analysis

title: Projects
text:
For this project, I used ArcGIS Pro to analyze and visualize cyanobacterial blooms in Pyramid Lake, NV. NDVI was calculated from Landsat 8-9 imagery for four bloom events, and a threshold of 0.25 was applied to identify areas of potential cyanobacterial activity. The slider app above displays a vectorized representation of NDVI for blooms that occurred on 10/29/2017, 9/22/2021, 10/6/2023 and 10/8/2024.
View the StoryMap here: Pyramid Lake Cyanobacterial Blooms
